contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox OS | name = JavaOS | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | website = | developer = [[Sun Microsystems]] | family = | source_model = Closed source | released = | latest_release_version = | latest_release_date = | latest_test_version = | latest_test_date = | marketing_target = | programmed_in = [[Java (programming language)|Java]] | language = | kernel_type = Microkernel | ui = | license = Proprietary | working_state = Discontinued | supported_platforms = [[ARM architecture|ARM]], [[PowerPC]], [[SPARC]], [[IA-32]] (x86) | updatemodel = | package_manager = }} '''JavaOS''' is an [[operating system]] with a [[Java virtual machine]] as a fundamental component, originally developed by [[Sun Microsystems]].<ref name="announce">{{cite press release |url = http://www.skytel.co.cr/wireless-communications/research/1996/0529-b.htm |title = JavaSoft Announces JavaOS |accessdate = 2011-12-16 |date = 1996-05-29 |publisher = JavaSoft ([[Sun Microsystems]]) }}</ref> Unlike Windows, Mac OS, [[Unix]] or [[Unix-like]] systems which are primarily written in the [[C (programming language)|C]] programming language, JavaOS is primarily written in [[Java (programming language)|Java]]. It is now considered a [[legacy system]].<ref name="CDCFAQ"/> == History == JavaOS was originally announced in 1996 by Sun's JavaSoft subsidiary as a compact OS designed to run "in anything from net computers to pagers".<ref name="announce"/> In 1998, Sun recruited [[IBM]] to accelerate its development.<ref>{{cite news | authorlink = | author = Mary Hayes | title = Sun Enlists IBM For JavaOS Aid | url = http://www.informationweek.com/670/70iusun.htm | work = [[InformationWeek]] | date = 1998-02-23 | accessdate = 2011-12-16 | quote = }}</ref> IBM indicated its focus was more on [[network computer]] thin clients, specifically to replace traditional "[[IBM 3270|green screen]]" and [[X terminal|UNIX terminal]]s, and to implement single application clients.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.itmweb.com/f031098.htm |title = Inside the IBM JavaOS Project |accessdate = 2011-12-16 |author = Russ Finney |date = 1998-03-10 |work = itmWEB }}</ref> In 1999, Sun and IBM announced the end of the JavaOS project.<ref name="CNet">{{cite news | author = Stephen Shankland | title = Sun, IBM decaffeinate JavaOS | url = http://news.cnet.com/2100-1001-230175.html | work = [[CNet News]] | date = 1999-08-23 | accessdate = 2011-12-16 }}</ref> As early as 2003, Sun materials referred to JavaOS as a "[[legacy system|legacy technology]]", recommending migration to [[Java ME]], leaving the choice of specific OS and Java environment to the implementer.<ref name="CDCFAQ">{{cite web | title = What is the migration path for the PersonalJava, EmbeddedJava and JavaOS technologies? | work = Connected Device Configuration FAQ | url=http://java.sun.com/products/cdc/faq.html#cp8 | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20030604120422/http://java.sun.com/products/cdc/faq.html | archivedate=2003-06-04 | accessdate = 2011-12-16}}</ref> == Design == The system is based on a hardware architecture native [[microkernel]]. The Java virtual machine runs on top of the microkernel. Platforms that the kernel runs on include: * [[ARM architecture|ARM]] * [[PowerPC]] * [[SPARC]] * [[StrongARM]] * [[IA-32]] All [[device driver]]s are written in Java and executed by the virtual machine. A graphics and windowing system implementing the [[Abstract Window Toolkit|AWT]] [[Application programming interface|API]] is also written in Java. == Applications == JavaOS was designed to run on [[embedded system]]s and has applications in devices such as [[set top box]]es, [[computer network|networking]] infrastructure and [[automatic teller machine|ATMs]]. It's also the operating system that comes with the [[JavaStation]]. == See also == {{Portal|Java}} * [[JNode]] * [[JX (operating system)]] * [[Sanos]] * [[SavaJe]] * [[Vino (operating system)]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == <!--* [http://www4.informatik.uni-erlangen.de/Projects/JX/index.html JX Java OS] WRONG PAGE--> * [http://java.sun.com/developer/products/JavaOS/ JavaOS SDK page] [[Category:Embedded operating systems]] [[Category:Java platform]] [[Category:Sun Microsystems software]] [[Category:ARM operating systems]]
